subject: Re: [junit] Thanks - running out of memory
msgSnippet: ... Like all things, this depends on context. If you re writing an application that will dominate the user environment, yes, being memory hungry isn t a crime.
messageBody:
On 23/01/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
> Speaking as one of those professionals, in a desktop or server
> environment buying RAM is cheaper than almost any other alternative.
> Most especially it's cheaper than rewriting the code to use less memory.
>
> Frankly, I'd fire a consultant who recommended continued hacking at $80
> an hour to save a byte here or a byte there instead of spending a few
> bucks to upgrade the RAM. In 2006 anyone who's running a desktop or a
> server with less than a gigabyte of RAM is being penny wise and very
> pound foolish.

Like all things, this depends on context. If you're writing an
application that will dominate the user environment, yes, being memory
hungry isn't a crime. If it needs to co-exist with several other
applications, then it is.

A server app running on a dedicated box can do what it wants. A Java
GUI app to process shipping orders that needs to be able to accessed
along with Word documents, Excel spreadsheets, and Outlook all runing
as well needs to be more parsimonious. A SWT application designed to
run as a status-bar extension probably can't even afford the overhead
of the JVM.

Even if the application is "worthy" of the extra memory, it may not be
cheaper to give it the memory. If you intend to deploy the application
to 10,000 machines in a corporate environment, the $50,000+ in parts
the memory upgrade will cost (before installation!) lets you afford a
few _months_ of improving the memory usage.

Context is crucial in any optimisation debate.
